posts.body:
Madam C.J. Walker

An American entrepreneur, Madam C.J. Walker (1867-1919) is today remembered as the first self-made millionaire in America.

Born Sarah Breedlove in Delta, Louisiana, Walker was the youngest of six siblings and the first freeborn person in her family. She was orphaned by the age of seven and only received three months of formal education, total, before she began working as a domestic servant as a child. She married for the first time at age 14, and after her husband’s death would marry twice more, though both of these marriages ended in divorce.

In 1888, she moved with her daughter, Lelia, to St. Louis and began working as a laundress, living near her brothers who were barbers. Walker suffered from dandruff and baldness until she learned to take care of her hair from her brothers and sold products for Annie Malone (another Black entrepreneurial woman who sold haircare products). Malone would later become Walker’s largest rival.

Walker set up shop in Denver, Colorado. She sold door-to-door and through the mail, selling products and teaching other Black women how to take care of their hair. She set up a beauty parlor in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, and Lelia College to train women to work in it. She trained people in the “Walker System” to sell products as a way to empower Black women financially.

At its height, Walker’s company employed thousands of women in multiple countries and she trained women in budgeting and financial literacy. She was vocal about her support of building Black wealth through the establishment of a YMBA in a Black neighborhood, supporting the Tuskegee Institute, and other Black educational institutions. She donated to the NAACP and the NACWC and helped to finance the preservation of Frederick Douglass’s house. She was also a patron of the arts, living in the middle of the Harlem Renaissance. Walk commissioned Vertner Tandy, the first Black architect in New York City, to design her house.

While Madam C.J. Walker is the first confirmed self-made female millionaire in America, it is worth noting that some sources suggest Mary Ellen Pleasant, a Black woman active in the California Gold Rush, did so first. Check back tomorrow to learn more about Pleasant, her philanthropy, and her abolition work!)

posts.body:
Winnaretta Singer

A lesbian royal, Winnaretta Singer (1864-1943) became a princess by entering a lavender marriage with a gay man. She spent her life supporting the arts and public health.

[Though primarily interested in music, Singer also painted, including this self-portrait c. 1885]

Singer was born in Yonkers, New York to the wealthy Singer family (of Singer sewing machines). As was true of many women from newly rich American families, she was married to an old and respectable but financially unstable European family. This was her first marriage, to Prince Louis de Scey-Montbéliard. On her wedding night, she reportedly threatened to kill him if he touched her, and their marriage lasted 5 years before it was annulled, on the grounds that the marriage was never consummated.

The next year, Singer married Prince Edmond de Polignac. Though she was 28 and he was 59, it was a happy marriage, because they were both gay. Singer and her husband were great friends and fellow artists, and Signer was free to pursue women without fear (except, occasionally, of those women’s husbands). Singer had a long list of confirmed partners, including American painter Virginia Woolf.

Singer funded a music salon that housed the first performances of such musicians as Chabrier, d'Indy, Debussy, Fauré, and Ravel. Her salon, indeed, was one of the best-observed salons and many of our ideas about salon culture were drawn from the Singer-Poignac salon. She also funded Stravinsky, Milhaud, and multiple ballets.

Singer was a leader in the development of Parisian public housing in the early 20th century, helped convert private limousines into mobile radiology units for World War I (working with Maria Skłodowska-Curie), and helped with the construction of Foch Hospital.

posts.body:
Susan Sontag

An American writer, philosopher, educator, and activist, Susan Sontag (1933-2004) was a New York City native who wrote extensively about art, illness, human rights, and leftism. Sontag has been described as “one of the most influential critics of her generation.”

Sontag was Jewish and an excellent scholar–she received her Bachelor’s degree from the University of Chicago when she was 18. She received her master’s in Philosophy at Harvard and taught. Sontag was a writer, and though her nonfictional essays are her most famous works, she considered herself a novelist. Sontag was openly bisexual and had relationships with both men and women.

Sontag was a role-model feminist and leftist. She vocally opposed the Vietnam War and the Siege of Sarajevo. She viewed American actions on the international stage as a form of imperialism. Sontag once said “The white race is the cancer of human history” due to its unique status as the only one which eradicates other civilizations and the environment. She later regretted this, considering it unfair to cancer patients, and wrote a book saying that illness should not be used as a metaphor.

posts.summary: Five Famous Native American Warrior Women
posts.body:
Five Famous Native American Warrior Women

These indigenous women fought against the United States Army at the Battle of the Little Bighorn, also called Custer’s Last Stand in defense of their lands and their people. For decades, their stories were kept alive through oral tradition and are just now beginning to get a wider spread.

1. One Who Walks With the Stars (Oglala Lakota) killed two soldiers at the Battle of the Little Bighorn

2. Pretty Nose (Arapaho) was a war chief who fought in the Battle of the Little Bighorn and lived to be over one hundred years old.

3. Tȟašína Máni (Sioux), also called Moving Robe Woman, fought in the Battle of the Little Bighorn to avenge her late brother, and she killed two men.

4. Minnie Hollow Wood (Lakota) fought at the Battle of the Little Bighorn and earned the right to wear a war bonnet–the only woman in her tribe who could do so.

5. Buffalo Calf Road Woman (Northern Cheyenne) saved her brother and struck Custer off his horse in battle.

posts.body:
Marjory Stoneman Douglas

The “Grande Dame of the Everglades”, Marjory Stoneman Douglas (1890-1998) was one of the most famous conservationists of the 20th century.

Born in Minneapolis, Minnesota to a fractured and unstable home life, Stoneman was incredibly successful in college but married a bigamist conman, whom she quickly left. It was in leaving him that she moved to Miami, where she would come across her life’s work.

She began working for her father writing for what would later become The Miami Herald, Miami’s main newspaper. She also joined the American Red Cross and served oversees in Paris during the signing of the the Armistice. After the war, she returned to Miami as an assistant editor for the newspaper, where she broke out of society gossip and began writing about urban planning, civil rights, women’s suffrage, and opposing Prohibition. One of her most important contributions was about the death of Martin Tabert, a prisoner who had died when he was leased out to perform work. Her writing contributed to the Florida Legislature banning convict leasing in its entirety.

Stoneman’s greatest contributions by far were to her never ceasing, decades-long quest to protect the Everglades. The Everglades are an incredibly important Neotropical wetlands with an ecosystem completely unique to anywhere else on Earth. At the time, however, it was mostly considered an ugly swamp, inevitably to be filled in and developed. She started the Friends of the Everglades when she was 79 years old and traveled, giving hundreds of speeches, denouncing a planned airport. Stoneman was directly critical of government and corporate entities, like Big Sugar and and the Army Corp of Engineers. As a result, she was a major enemy of many politicians and businessmen.

When Marjory Stoneman Douglas died, she was 108 years old. She didn’t start her most important project until she was nearly 80, but she fought for it with unending passion. Today, the Everglades remain one of the most important and certainly the most unique ecosystem in the United States thanks to her work.

posts.body:
Mai Bhago

Sometimes called the “Sikh Joan of Arc”, Mai Bhago (17th-18th century) was a Sikh warrior woman who is now venerated as a saint in Sikhism.

Born in Chabal Kalan in what is now Punjab, to an important and religious family. She learned Shaster vidya, a form of martial arts taught by Sikh gurus using stick-fighting. In 1705, when the Mughals invaded, 40 Sikhs abandoned their people and their Guru because they were told they would be spared. Mai Bhago openly criticized and shamed them for their disloyalty and rallied these deserters, convincing them to return to Guru Gobind Singh and apologize.

During this time, the Mughals attacked Guru Gobind Singh and forced him and his people forced to flee. They met up with Mai Bhago and her men in Khidrana, where they attacked and defeated the Mughals. All 40 of the men following her died, and Mai Bhago was severely injured, but they succeeded in forcing a Mughal retreat.

After the battle, Mai Bhago became a bodyguard of Guru Gobind Singh, dressing in men’s clothes and dual-wielding a musket and a lance (the lance weighed over 100 pounds|45kg). She did this until his death, when she retired.

Today, Mai Bhago is remembered as the first Sikh woman to take up arms against oppressors.

posts.body:
Did You Know?

The marathon at the 1904 Summer Olympics was one of the least successful in the world. Of the 40 athletes who entered, only 32 actually competed and only 14 actually finished the race. Of these 14, only 4 had their final times known, and of these 4, 1 was disqualified (for being driven for 11 miles).

posts.body:
Mae Mallory

[Mae Mallory and her daughter]

A Civil Rights and Black Power leader, Mae Mallory (1927-2007) was an advocate for Black self-defense and desegregation.

Born in Macon, Georgia and raised in New York City, Mallory believed in self-determination and self-empowerment. In 1957, she filed a suit against the New York City Board of Education, alleging that her children still want to de facto segregated schools despite the Brown decision three years previous. She was joined by eight other mothers, and the so-called Harlem Nine won the right to transfer their children.

In the 1960s, after supporting the Freedom Riders, Mallory was confronted with White supremacists and unfairly targeted by the police. She was arrested in Cleveland and held at the Cuyahoga County Jail, where she gave an interview. In this interview, she argued that capitalism made enemies of working-class White and Black Americans who ought to have been compatriots, criticism Black liberal leaders as being too moderate, and argued for the necessity of Black self-defense.

She was eventually extradited and the guilty verdict was overturned, and she spent the rest of her life fighting for her people.

posts.body:
Arcangela Tarabotti

An early protofeminist and nun, Arcangela Tarabotti (1604-1652) was an Early Modern Italian writer. Today considered one of the first political theorists, her seven works (five published) covered systems of misogyny in contemporary life.

Tarabotti was one of eleven children and was physically disabled. She began boarding at the Benedictine convent of Sant'Anna when she was 11, likely in part because her disability made her a less desirable wife.

As a nun, she was openly rebellious and felt that she was ‘living a lie’ as a nun, she was disdainful of monastic rules and authorities. She did take advantage of her situation to educate herself, though she was separate from outside society (though she often had correspondence and visitors from outside, in flagrant disregard of the rules).

Her politics were radical–Tarabotti critiqued misogyny in the Catholic Church and politics and argues for increased access to education for women. Her most prized and unorthodox work, Paternal Tyranny, discusses three forms of structural power that work together to subjugate women: the state, the church, and gender roles.

posts.body:
Milena Rudnytska

A Ukrainian educator and writer Milena Rudnytska (1892-1976) founded one of the largest feminist organizations in Europe.

Rudnytska was born in Zboriv (now western Ukraine) in the Austro-Hungarian Empire to a Ukrainian father and a Galician Jewish mother. During World War I, her family moved to Vienna, Austria where she received a teaching degree and began working as a journalist. In 1920, Rudnytska returned to Ukraine where she began to focus on two simultaneous goals: the Ukrainian national movement and the empowerment of women in Ukraine.

She helped found and became one of the leaders of the Ukrainian Women’s Union, a community-led organization focused on social and economic improvement for women in Ukraine. She was elected to represent Ukraine in the parliament of Poland (which then held Ukraine). She represented the Ukrainian nationalist movement to the international community, including the League of Nations.

Throughout her life, she continued to work. In the European interwar period and during World War II, Rudnytska began to be watched by both the Soviets and the Nazis, who she had vocally criticized for the restrictive policies for women.

Much of the modern feminist movement in Ukraine, and much of Europe, are thanks to Milena Rudnytska.

posts.summary: The Grand Princess Olga of Kyiv
posts.body:
The Grand Princess Olga of Kyiv

One of the most famous Ukrainian women in history Olga [sometimes Volga, Helga, or Olena, Elena] (around 900-925) of Kyiv was a ruler and a saint.

Born in Pleskov of Varangian (Viking, thus Swedish) origin and married at 15 years old to Prince Igor I of Kyiv, Princess Olga spent most of her life in Kyiv, then the center of the Rurik dynasty and now the capital of Ukraine. At the time of her husband’s reign, Kyiv was the center of the Kyivan Rus, a loose tribal federation, which fought with (meaning sometimes as allies and sometimes as enemies) the Drevlians

When the Drevlians stopped paying tribute and killed Igor, Olga began to lead as regent on behalf of her son Sviatoslav (then three years old). The Drevlians attempted to force Olga into marriage with Prince Mal, the man who murdered her late husband. Pretending to go along with it, Olga instead had the Drevlian ambassadors buried alive. Then she asked the Drevlians to send their best men, to escort her with honor, and she locked them in a bathhouse and set them all on fire. Then she got them to send a third of contingent of important Drevlian men, who she had murdered. Then she got together her army and went to war against the Drevlians, where she won rather easily, except the city of Iskorosten (now Korosten, Ukraine). She promised to end the siege for the small price of three birds from every house, and then sent those birds back ablaze and the city burned down.

Olga’s revenge quest is her most interesting story, but it is worth noting that, as Ukraine’s first female ruler, she was an excellent stateswoman. She expanded the lands she ruled and revamped the tribute system (the first known legal reform in all of Eastern Europe!), evaded more marriage proposals, established hunting grounds, towns, and trading posts.

She converted to Christianity and is venerated as a saint in the Eastern Orthodox Church.
